utterances.utterance: I would find it very difficult, I was saying in that article, to strike down a provision on the basis of substantive due process.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It went on, but the larger question was about abortion. And he said, the 14th Amendment? Does it have two layers.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.utterance: Why was no one there, though? That's amazing compared to what it is today.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.utterance: That is incredible.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And the first day there were his kids.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.utterance: And the recording at the time during that hearing --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But the most fun thing about that, guys, we have to do this on the show. The most fun thing is that in the background, you saw Anthony Podesta or what it John Podesta? John Podesta, you saw all these people, young, they were young. They were sitting behind all these senators, Biden and Kennedy and Howard Metzenbaum. Oh, no, Hatch is like really young, and McConnell is really young.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's wild. It's like memory lane here. All right, guys, great panel. We'll see what happens. We wish her the very best. Up next, the entitled teen calling the cops on her dad, and the untold story of that viral Gillette ad. Raymond Arroyo here, special Thursday edition of "The Follies," next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's time for, what, "Thursday Follies?" Well, it's a special edition. What can I say? What about that bizarre Gillette ad, what was that really all about? And is it stealing if you take a kid's cellphone away? Plus, January turns into Janu-hairy. Joining us now with all the details is Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor, "New York Times" bestselling author of the upcoming smash "Will Wilder, The Amulet of Power." Get it if you want your kids to read and love it. Raymond, Gillette is facing a little bit of backlash, or serious backlash, for this ad.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's been going on far too long. You can't laugh it off.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What I actually think she's trying to say.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Making the same old excuses.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys. Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But some things finally changed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Men need to hold other men accountable.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Smile, sweetie. Come on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: To say the right thing, to act the right way, because the boys watching today will be the men of tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: When did selling razors turn into a scolding of men? The tagline is "The best a man can get." This is the worst ad a man can watch. Laura, here's what most people don't know. A lot of people saw the ad, they copied it, sent it around. In 2011, Gillette learned that 30 percent of their customers were women who use the men's razors. With beards making a comeback, guys aren't buying the razors like they once did, but women might. So they devised this men need to change campaign to attract the ladies. In the process, it feminizes men, and the director was a woman named Kim Gehrig. She has directed short films on toxic masculinity and celebrating female genitalia.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Lovely.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: We won't show clips from that one.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Compare that add we just showed you to the original "The best a man could get" ad from 1989. Watch.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You're looking good, you've come so far. We know how to make the most of who you are. Father to son, it's what we've always done.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The best a man can get

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Gillette, the best a man can get.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You can't show traditional marriage at all.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The best a man can get is married with children, mentoring your son.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Sensitive, but sensitive.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But you see, this new ad, the new version of this is really man as a wuss. You are bad. And that line of the guys at the barbecue pits intoning, boys will be boys. Imagine a summer's even ad with a bunch of ladies barefoot and naked -- barefoot and pregnant in a kitchen. Imagine that ad. People would naturally be offended. A lot of people would be offended by this stereotype of guys just sitting there at the barbeque.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Television has been doing the men are dumb and stupid.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The media has been telling us that for decades.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They've been telling us that story. But they think that women are attracted to the Apple guy, or the whatever --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The Verizon guy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Or the Verizon guy. I'm sure there are sweet people, but I don't think. And we asked the twentysomethings out here which ad they liked better, they like the original ad. Twentysomethings.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I ask young guys in my circle, I said watch this, tell me what you think. Most of them wanted to take a razor and slit their throats after watching.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Now, in the 80s and 90s, Laura, they were selling masculinity to men and women. Watch these ads we found.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I don't need some fancy cologne to tell me I'm a man. I use skin bracer, it smells great. But it also cools and tones my skir. Confidence is very sexy, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I dare you to knock this off. I dare you to compare anybody's batteries, anybody's, to alkaline power cells. Try and beat them for long life. You know what, you can't. Go on, I dare you.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The tough guy -- the tough guy --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So cute. My God.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Women were attracted to him, men want to be like that. They want to be strong. I loved Jack Palance.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So great.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I know what it takes to be a man. Love that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So advertisers are trying to feminize men.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Right, while women are going in a different direction. Last week feminists launched this campaign, Laura, to raise awareness about what they called the oppressiveness of traditional gender norms, and they want to advocate body positivity.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, brother.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: To do so, they encouraged women to grow up there body hair throughout the month of Janu-hairy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What the?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: So women have taken to Instagram. Oh, Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She has really hairy legs. This is why petticoats and long skirts were --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bringing back the hoopskirts, are we, Arroyo.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: This is nasty. I'm sorry, I just have to tell you. I guess the idea is to make women as unappealing as possible to men and vice versa. I guess that is what the dynamic is here, because why would you do this to yourself?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I remember in college, it was a big deal when you would traveled overseas, that in France and Russia, places where I was, that women didn't shave. It was a cultural thing, they didn't shave. But people were grossed out by it.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: OK, we've got to go before we run out of time. Is it legal to take your child's phone away, Laura? In South Euclid, Ohio, cops were called when an entitled teen made this call.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: 911, what is your emergency?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: My father took property which was an $800 phone that doesn't belong to him.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The cops show up at the door of Anthony Robertson after his daughter called, and they let their body cams on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I took her phone from her because she's a juvenile. I don't want her to have it. She won't let me inspect it, so I took it from her.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's not his property, it's mine. He never asked to inspect it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Guess what? Everything that you own belongs to your mother and your father. They don't want you to have it, you don't have it. Having a phone is not a right, it's a privilege, OK? You don't need a cell phone.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The other police officer said, you want your phone back? Start listening to your parents.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It's not an entitlement. It's not a right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The police have so much on their hands and now they are having to give life advice to people.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But good for that father who was intervening. He took the phone from his daughter. And you know what he's worried about, the apps where she's hiding things from him. He doesn't want that going on. He took the phone.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: There's a weird image, an interesting image that showed up, Chad Pergram tweeted it out, the March for Life is tomorrow, the Center Stone Rotunda at the capital. What does that look like, Raymond?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It looks like a Eucharistic host, really. It is the Center Stone in the Rotunda.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And you can see tonight or yesterday, you can see a cross. No one had seen that before.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: No, I'd never seen that before.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: People are saying it's maybe --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: A sign,

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: A sign.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Coming up, European leaders lob insults at President Trump over his supposed cozy relationship with Putin. We ask this question, who is really engaging in Russian collusion? The U.S. ambassador to Germany Ric Grenell joins us exclusively to explain.

utterances.speaker: JOE SCARBOROUGH, MSNBC HOST
utterances.utterance: Right now, there's a question within a sizable chunk of America whether Donald Trump is working on behalf of Russia.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MAZIE HIRONO, D-HI
utterances.utterance: Whose side is the president on, Russia's side or our side? Basically, he spouts Putin's allies.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, MSNBC HOST
utterances.utterance: He wants to give Russia every item on its most fantastical international wish list. Putin now has a president of the United States who performs backflips on command.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Gosh, they have to be better than that. Come on, guys. Is that a common refrain, what's really the case? Why is the president warning European leaders, even threatening European leaders with sanctions over a proposed Russian pipeline project called Nord Stream 2? We've talked about this a lot on radio, now on the podcast, and of course on TV. The project would make much of Europe, especially Germany, dependent on Russian gas. So if Trump were really best buds with Putin, why the heck would he stand in the way of Russian having this huge infusion of cash? Joining me now exclusively, U.S. ambassador to Germany Ric Grenell. He is totally jetlagged, but he's staying up late for us. Mr. Ambassador, great to see you in person. What part of this story are the American people not getting if they are immersed in that kind of media?

utterances.speaker: RICHARD GRENELL, U.S. AMBASSADOR TO GERMANY
utterances.utterance: Look, I think you just look at the facts, and this president has been very tough on the Russians. At the same time, it's a dual track approach, which I think is beginning to be the Trump doctrine, which is this dual track. We are going to base our policy in reality, but we're going to also offer the ability to be idealistic if you change your behavior, maybe --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Offramp.

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: Yes. Maybe we can have some sort of talk. But just look at the facts. We've been very tough on Russia. The president has been extremely clear that this gas pipeline from Russia going into Europe is the wrong idea. And by the way, the president is with most of the European Union, the European parliament. There's 18 European countries that have stood up to say we don't think that more Russian gas in Europe or in Germany is the right way to go. We want a diversification policy in all of Europe. So the president is standing with the European Union.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But the president also is getting -- he's getting hammered day after day after day, the drip-drip-drip, Mueller and all that. And you see the president being tarred with he's not for NATO, because he is a businessman and he wants to support NATO, but he wants other countries to pay their fair share. But today, and I know a lot of ambassadors are in town, today he was at the Pentagon and he talked about NATO. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We cannot be the fools for others. We are going to be with NATO 100 percent. But as I told the countries, you have to step up. You have pay minimum numbers, actually, that they set a two percent goal. Very few pay that. But they should be much higher than that. Look at what we pay, it's massively higher than that. Countries are now stepping up, and they can well afford to.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK, so he says all that, Ambassador, Grenell, but then you have Congressman Gregory Meeks from New York going on television and saying this.

utterances.speaker: REP. GREGORY MEEKS, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: He is a guy that I would believe that if you talked to him three or four years because running for president, he probably didn't even know what NATO is, but now he has devalued NATO and the E.U. to such a degree that it is plausible to me that he would have had this backdoor conversation with Vladimir Putin about withdrawing from NATO.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I'm just hearing this, and like, you've got to be kidding me. This is rank speculation. The CNN reporter is nodding, oh, yes, good point.

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: Look, the reality is that the president is strengthening NATO. We've had the same policy for decades that countries should be racing their spend, they should be meeting the NATO commitment of two percent. They have ignored us for a very long time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They've been taking us for chumps.

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: President Obama had the same policy -- raise your spending. They ignored us. But now countries are beginning to raise their spending. So I would argue, actually, Laura, the person who tries to reform multilateral organizations is the one who cares the most about them. Rather than ignore them and let them adrift, let them not deal with today's threats, let them have members that don't pay their bills, if you allow that to happen, I would argue that you actually don't care about those agencies. But when you do the hard work of engaging and trying to reform agencies exactly how the president is doing it, then I think there's an argument to be made is he is the one who cares more about NATO because he wants it to work better. And it clearly needs reforming.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What is it like for you as ambassador to Germany, one of the most important ambassadorial positions? You had quite a splash right in the beginning when you first assumed the position. German media goes after Ambassador Ric Grenell, here's one of the headlines. "Trump's ambassador finds few friends in Germany. Since arriving in Berlin as U.S. ambassador to Germany, Grenell has flouted diplomatic conventions and attempted to interfere in domestic politics. He has since become politically isolated in the German capital." Do you have no friends, Ric? Do you need a visit? Do I need to come visit you?

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: Look, I think that there's a very good argument to be made that President Obama was wildly popular in Germany.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You think?

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: But the German government killed his T-TIP. They didn't return the Nazi prison guard that he had been asking for.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: T-TIP, the trade deal.

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: T-TIP is the trade deal, Obama's signature trade deal. The Nazi prison guard who was living here, the Obama administration asked for a very long time to have him returned. We have been asking for a very long time for defense spending to be raised, and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which was all started under President Obama. So I think the tough talk from President Trump is working.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So they liked a weaker United States. They loved him because he's a global superstar, a pop star for them, but they loved a weaker United States that wasn't going to challenge.

utterances.speaker: GRENELL
utterances.utterance: We want a stronger relationship, and that means reforming it and pushing and trying to get both sides --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I'm glad you're there, and I'm glad that you stopped by, and thank you for fighting jetlag to be here. Ric Grenell, an important day tomorrow, but will the media cover it? Stay there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tomorrow hundreds of thousands will descend on Washington for the pro-life march, the longest march in U.S. history. It's likely going to get just a little squib article probably in "The Washington Post," but that's OK. They are standing for those who can't speak for themselves, the most defenseless among us, and it's amazing. And the young people showing up, we're all with you. New poll finding millennials, largest group of American voters are not in lockstep with the Democrats on abortion, 41 percent said they want Roe versus Wade overturned, seven and 10, said they support some limits. Like parental notification, blocking abortions at five months of pregnancy and funding government abortions, forget it. They're not for that. Well, I hope the media maybe pays attention.
